concepts.concept_name: Chemical reactions and their characteristics
Writing and balancing chemical equations
Types of chemical reactions: combination, decomposition, displacement, double displacement
Oxidation and reduction reactions
Effects of oxidation in everyday life: corrosion and rancidity

in_scope: Signs of a chemical reaction: change in colour, temperature, state, gas evolution
Chemical equation as a shorthand representation
Balanced and unbalanced chemical equations
Law of conservation of mass in balancing equations
Combination reaction: two or more substances combine to form one product
Decomposition reaction: single compound breaks into simpler substances
Thermal decomposition, electrolytic decomposition, photodecomposition
Displacement reaction: more reactive element displaces less reactive one
Double displacement reaction: exchange of ions between two reactants
Precipitation reactions
Exothermic and endothermic reactions
Oxidation: gain of oxygen or loss of hydrogen
Reduction: loss of oxygen or gain of hydrogen
Redox reactions: simultaneous oxidation and reduction
Corrosion of metals (rusting of iron, tarnishing of silver, green coating on copper)
Rancidity: oxidation of fats and oils
Methods to prevent corrosion and rancidity
out_of_scope: Electron transfer concept of oxidation-reduction — Class 11-12
Oxidation number and half-reaction method — Class 11-12
Thermochemistry and enthalpy calculations — Class 11-12
Electrochemical cells and electrode potentials — Class 12

concepts.concept_name: Properties and indicators for acids and bases
Reactions of acids and bases with metals, metal oxides, and metal carbonates
Neutralisation and the pH scale
Importance of pH in everyday life
Salts: preparation, properties, and uses of common salts

in_scope: Acids: sour taste, turn blue litmus red, produce H+ ions in solution
Bases: bitter taste, soapy feel, turn red litmus blue, produce OH- ions
Indicators: litmus, phenolphthalein, methyl orange, turmeric
Olfactory indicators
Acid + metal → salt + hydrogen gas
Base + metal → salt + hydrogen gas (for amphoteric metals)
Acid + metal carbonate/bicarbonate → salt + water + CO2
Acid + base → salt + water (neutralisation)
Reaction of metallic oxides with acids
Reaction of non-metallic oxides with bases
Strong and weak acids and bases
pH scale: 0 to 14
pH of neutral, acidic, and basic solutions
Importance of pH in soil, digestive system, tooth decay, self-defence by animals
Common salt (NaCl) and its importance
Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) from chlor-alkali process
Baking soda (NaHCO3): properties and uses
Washing soda (Na2CO3·10H2O): preparation and uses
Plaster of Paris (CaSO4·½H2O): preparation and uses
Bleaching powder (CaOCl2): preparation and uses
Water of crystallisation
out_of_scope: Arrhenius, Bronsted-Lowry, Lewis theory of acids and bases — Class 11-12
Buffer solutions and Henderson-Hasselbalch equation — Class 11-12
Ionic equilibrium and solubility product — Class 11-12
Titration calculations and volumetric analysis — Class 11-12

concepts.concept_name: Physical properties of metals and non-metals
Chemical properties of metals
Reactivity series and its applications
Ionic bonding and properties of ionic compounds
Extraction of metals and prevention of corrosion

in_scope: Physical properties of metals: lustre, malleability, ductility, conductivity, sonorous
Physical properties of non-metals: brittle, poor conductors, dull
Exceptions: mercury (liquid metal), iodine (lustrous non-metal), diamond (hard non-metal)
Reaction of metals with oxygen to form basic/amphoteric oxides
Reaction of non-metals with oxygen to form acidic oxides
Reaction of metals with water
Reaction of metals with acids
Reaction of metals with salt solutions (displacement)
Reactivity series of metals: K, Na, Ca, Mg, Al, Zn, Fe, Pb, H, Cu, Hg, Ag, Au
Ionic bond formation by transfer of electrons
Properties of ionic compounds: high melting/boiling point, soluble in water, conduct electricity in solution/molten state
Occurrence of metals: native and combined states
Extraction: enrichment of ores, roasting, calcination, reduction
Thermite reaction
Electrolytic refining
Corrosion prevention: painting, oiling, greasing, galvanisation, electroplating, alloying
Alloys: definition and common examples (brass, bronze, solder, amalgam, stainless steel)
out_of_scope: Metallic bonding and band theory — Class 11-12
Ellingham diagram for extraction — Class 12
Coordination compounds — Class 12
Crystal field theory — Class 12

concepts.concept_name: Bonding in carbon: covalent bond and versatile nature of carbon
Saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons
Homologous series and nomenclature of carbon compounds
Functional groups and chemical properties of carbon compounds
Important carbon compounds: ethanol and ethanoic acid

in_scope: Covalent bond: sharing of electrons
Properties of covalent compounds: low melting/boiling points, poor conductors
Allotropes of carbon: diamond, graphite, fullerene (Buckminsterfullerene)
Tetravalency of carbon and ability to form four bonds
Catenation: ability of carbon to form bonds with other carbon atoms
Saturated hydrocarbons (alkanes): single bonds only
Unsaturated hydrocarbons: alkenes (double bonds), alkynes (triple bonds)
Straight chain and branched chain hydrocarbons
Cyclic hydrocarbons (introduction)
Homologous series: definition, characteristics, general formula
IUPAC nomenclature of simple carbon compounds (up to 10 carbons)
Functional groups: alcohol (-OH), aldehyde (-CHO), ketone (C=O), carboxylic acid (-COOH), halogen
Combustion of carbon compounds
Oxidation of alcohols to carboxylic acids
Addition reaction of unsaturated hydrocarbons
Substitution reaction of saturated hydrocarbons
Ethanol: properties and uses, harmful effects of drinking alcohol
Ethanoic acid (acetic acid): properties and uses
Soaps and detergents: cleaning action, micelle formation
out_of_scope: Orbital hybridisation (sp, sp2, sp3) — Class 11
Isomerism in detail (structural, geometrical, optical) — Class 11
Reaction mechanisms (SN1, SN2, electrophilic addition) — Class 11-12
Polymers and macromolecules — Class 12

concepts.concept_name: Early attempts at classification: Dobereiner's triads and Newlands' Law of Octaves
Mendeleev's periodic table: achievements and limitations
Modern periodic table: periods, groups, and periodic law
Trends in the modern periodic table

in_scope: Need for classification of elements
Dobereiner's triads: arithmetic mean of atomic masses
Limitations of Dobereiner's triads
Newlands' Law of Octaves: every eighth element has similar properties
Limitations of Newlands' Law of Octaves
Mendeleev's periodic law: properties are periodic function of atomic mass
Mendeleev's periodic table: arrangement by atomic mass
Achievements: prediction of undiscovered elements (Eka-boron, Eka-aluminium, Eka-silicon)
Accommodation of noble gases
Limitations: anomalous pairs, position of isotopes, no fixed position for hydrogen
Modern periodic law: properties are periodic function of atomic number
Modern periodic table: 18 groups and 7 periods
Position of element based on electronic configuration
Valence electrons determine group number
Number of shells determines period number
Trends in valency across a period and down a group
Trends in atomic size across a period (decreases) and down a group (increases)
Trends in metallic and non-metallic character
Trends in electronegativity (introduction)
out_of_scope: Detailed electronic configuration with sub-shells — Class 11
Ionisation energy, electron affinity calculations — Class 11
d-block and f-block elements in detail — Class 11-12
Effective nuclear charge and shielding — Class 11
